Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: They must follow strict procedures for a large cash deposit at the end of a busy shift to comply with corporate auditing rules.
Story: The clock above the register blinked 8:55 p.m., five minutes before closing. My hands moved automatically, counting the thick stack of bills for the end-of-shift deposit. The store was quiet, but my phone buzzed in my pocket—a reminder for my weekly call home. Mom and Dad would be waiting, probably sitting together on the couch, expecting to hear about my week and to tell me about theirs. I could almost hear Mom’s gentle voice, “Don’t forget to call, okay?” But the deposit procedure was strict: recount, log, double-check, lock away. If I missed a step, I could get written up or worse. My manager had drilled it into us—no shortcuts, no distractions. I felt the pressure mounting, torn between the warmth of my parents’ expectations and the cold, unyielding rules of the store. My fingers hesitated over the bills, my phone vibrating again. I stood there, caught between the duty of a son and the responsibility of a cashier, heart pounding as I tried to decide which role to answer first.
